Your K' isn't going to be isomorphic to the kernel in general. You need more conditions for that.
I thought this is the universal property of kernels. I copied it from Wikipedia.

It's usually a good idea to have a look at the file where the construction is defined, in this case file#category_theory/limits/shapes/kernels. The docstring at the top explains the API.

What you posted can be called "the universal property of kernels" (except as Johan pointed out, K' â‰… kernel f should read K' âŸ¶ kernel f), but note that there are usually a couple different equivalent ways of stating a universal property. Mathlib's kernel API is divided into more components: docs#category_theory.limits.kernel.lift will give you the function u, kernel.lift_Î¹ gives you its defining property, and I believe there should be an instance saying that kernel.Î¹ is mono which gives you uniqueness.
